SEARCH
Module iu.util.type
Package edu.iu.type

Interface IuComponent

All Superinterfaces:
AutoCloseable
All Known Implementing Classes:
Component
public interface IuComponent extends AutoCloseable
Facade interface representing an application component.

A component is defined by one or more Java (jar) Archives. Components are named, versioned, and isolated at runtime.

Component Archives

A component archive provides the resources and type definitions for a component. Each component archive must be validated before the component may be loaded.

All component archives must:

  • Be a jar archive built using Apache Maven.
  • Not be directory in a file system, either originally or unpacked.
  • Include a well-formed manifest in META-INF/MANIFEST.MF.
  • Not include Main-Class in the manifest's main attribute section.
  • Include exactly one META-INF/maven/.../pom.properties entry.

Modular Components

Components should be modular. A Modular component that includes module-info.class in its archive must meet all requirements of the Java Module System.

A component archive that does not include module-info.class may still be treated as a modular component as long as it doesn't have any legacy dependencies.

Legacy Components

To preserve compatibility for components that depend on IU JEE 6, Servlet 4, and EJB 3 legacy components with such dependencies must be loaded in an unnamed module by a class loader that does not delegate to the system class loader.

A component must be loaded as a legacy components if its archive does not include module-info.class and meets at least one of the following additional criteria:

  • Does not include Extension-List in its manifest's main attributes section, or if Extension-List includes javax.servlet-api, javax.ejb-api, jakarta.servlet-api with version < 6.0, or jakarta.ejb-api with version < 4.0. If both module-info.class and a legacy dependency is named, the component will be loaded as modular.
  • Includes META-INF/iu.properties. When both META-INF/iu.properties and module-info.class are present, the archive will be rejected with IllegalArgumentException.

Types defined by legacy components that depend on packages named javax.* may be converted to access equivalent types named jakarta.* when an equivalent package is inherited from a modular parent component. To facilitate this consideration, type references and annotated elements may automatically be converted to non-legacy equivalents when performing introspection on legacy components.

Legacy components may consider "should" requirements outlined below as optional.

Dependencies

A component may depend on other components. All dependencies must be present in the component's path, or as dependencies of its parent component, when the component is loaded.

Dependencies may be provided to a component's path by passing additional InputStream entries to of(InputStream, InputStream...) or extend(InputStream, InputStream...).

Dependencies may be added to a component's path by bundling jars in its archive. Component archives with bundled dependencies should include a Class-Path entry in the manifest's main attribute section. Bundled dependencies must not also be provided.

Dependencies may be inherited from a parent component. Inherited dependencies must not also be bundled or provided.

Components should enumerate dependencies using the Extension-List manifest attribute. When present, the dependencies referred to in the extension list will be enforced using pom.properties artifactId and version as present the component's path or inherited by its parent component.

Note that Extension-List was originally intended for applets, which are no longer supported by Java SE or related products. However, JEE 10 Section 8.2.2 requires this attribute to be supported for all component types, and clarifies by example that extension-Specification-Version may be used to declare that an installed library meet a minimum specification version as opposed to declaring a specific extension-Implementation-Version. This requirement by JEE 10 supersedes the implied deprecation of Extension-List by Java SE.

Maven Archiver includes support for generating the Class-Path and Extension-List attributes from the project's dependency artifacts.

  • The addClasspath configuration parameter may be true to enumerate all compile and runtime scoped dependencies in the Class-Path attribute. However, this does not bundle the related artifacts in the resulting component archive. When using addClasspath, a component archive's Maven project should also configure the Maven Dependency Plugin to copy related artifacts from the local Maven repository into the archive's output folder. For example: 
       <plugin>
      <artifactId>maven-jar-plugin</artifactId>
      <executions>
        <execution>
          <id>default-jar</id>
          <configuration>
            <archive>
              <manifest>
                <addClasspath>true</addClasspath>
                <classpathPrefix>META-INF/lib</classpathPrefix>
              </manifest>
            </archive>
          </configuration>
        </execution>
      </executions>
    </plugin>
    <plugin>
      <artifactId>maven-dependency-plugin</artifactId>
      <executions>
        <execution>
          <id>embed-dependencies</id>
          <phase>process-resources</phase>
          <goals>
            <goal>copy-dependencies</goal>
          </goals>
          <configuration>
            <outputDirectory>${project.build.outputDirectory}/META-INF/lib</outputDirectory>
          </configuration>
        </execution>
      </executions>
    </plugin>
  • Maven Archiver documentation as well as the Maven Archiver source code related to addExtensions reveal only minimal support for Extension-List with caveats related to applets indicated in inline comments. This configuration parameter may be used by a component archive's Maven project to declare that specific versions of all compile and runtime scoped dependencies be provided to the component. The addExtensions archive configuration parameter should not be true when addClasspath is also true.

Class Loading

IuComponent is an application bootstrap utility that shields loaded components from class loading and type introspection details. An application that uses the iu.util.type module to compose components should include iu-java-type.jar in the JVM module path.

A component must not have access to the iu.util.type module instance it was loaded from or to any other module instances present in the same module layer.

A component may list the iu.util.type module as a dependency. When listed as a dependency, the iu.util.type module instance available to the component must exist in a separate layer from the instance that loaded the component.

Regardless of which iu.util.type module instance loaded a component, Types loaded by the component must not have access to types loaded by the system class loader. Types loaded by the system class loader must not be visible to types loaded by the component.

Conversely, types loaded by the system class loader, especially all types in the iu.util.type module must have access to all types in all components.

Components may be extended. An extended component includes all types defined by its parent component and delegates to its parent component's class loader. A component must not have access to other components extended from the same parent.

Web Component

A component may be defined by a Web Application Archive. Web components should adhere to the requirements outlined in Java Servlet 6.0 Section 10.

Web components must only bundle dependencies in the WEB-INF/lib/ folder, and should not include the Class-Path manifest attribute.

A web component should include Extension-List in its manifest's main attributes section to declare all provided dependencies.

A web component must not be listed as a dependency.

Unsupported Component Formats

Support for the formats outlined in this section are out of scope and will result in IllegalArgumentException when passed to of(InputStream, InputStream...).

Enterprise Application Archives

An Enterprise Application Archive (ear) contains components. The IU JEE 7 Enterprise Archive implementation will consume this interface to compose applications, but an ear is not a component and must not be supplied to the of(InputStream, InputStream...) method.

Resource Adapter Archives

An Resource Adapter Archive (rar) contains Java and non-Java shared library archives. The IU JEE 7 Resource Adapter implementation will consume this interface to compose resource adapters, but a rar file is not a component and must not be supplied to the of(InputStream, InputStream...) method.

Shaded (Uber-)Jar Archive

Maven provides the shade plugin for creating "uber-jar" archives that flatten all dependencies into a single archive. While this format is useful for creating executable jars and other types of standalone Java applications, it breaks encapsulation and so is considered an anti-pattern for runtime-composable application components. An uber-jar must not be supplied to the of(InputStream, InputStream...) method.

    • interfaces

      Iterable<? extends IuType<?,?>> interfaces()
      Gets all of the component's public interfaces.

      This method is intended to support resource and service discovery of public APIs defined by the applications. A modular component Must not include interfaces from a module that does not open the package containing the interface to the iu.util.type.impl module. A legacy component Must not include interfaces from any dependencies unless the dependency is a IuComponent.Kind.LEGACY_JAR that includes an META-INF/iu.properties resource.

      Returns:
      interface facades

    • resources

      Iterable<? extends IuResource<?>> resources()
      Gets component's resources.

      Includes:

      • Static web resources when kind().isWeb() is true, with type byte[]. This includes zero-length binary resources for folder entries (IuResource.name() ends with '/').
      • All types in the component and all dependencies declared as part of an package open to iu.util.type.impl, or in a legacy component with META-INF/iu.properties, that includes the @Resource or @Resources annotation where either the resource type designated by the annotation is assignable from the annotated type, or the designated type is an interface and the annotated type is an InvocationHandler.

      Must not include resources available from ClassLoader.getResources(String) and related methods. Although the name and functionality are similar, the iu.util.type module is intended only to simplify, not duplicate, base platform functionality provided by the platform.

      This method discovers resources in a manner that deviates from the behavior described in Jakarta Annotations 2.1 Section 3.3. This deviation from the standard is an important element of IU JEE's self-defining behavior for application resources, and eliminates the need for a deployment descriptor that describes the resources available to a component.

      The standard specification describes the behavior of @Resource on a type as declaring a dependency that must be available for lookup via JNDI and requires that name() be non-empty. That behavior should be preserved for cases when the resource type is not assignable from the annotated type, however when the resource type is assignable or is and interface and the annotated type implements InvocationHandler, the annotated type itself is considered the resource implementation type and the default resource name is the simple name of resource type. When the annotated type is an InvocationHandler, then the resource type must be an interface in order to be discovered, otherwise the default resource type is the first non-platform interface implemented by the resource implementation type, or the resource implementation type itself if no non-platform interfaces are implemented.

      Resources discovered in this manner use IuExecutable.exec(Object...) with no args to create an instance. When shareable(), IuResource.get() returns a pre-constructed single instance; else each invocation returns a new instance. When the annotated type is an InvocationHandler, a Proxy is created with the resource type as its only interface.

      Note that resources provided by this method do not have field or property bindings applied. That binding behavior would require a fully formed JNDI context be available and is the responsibility JEE Container, via the iu.jee.resources module, not this base utilities module.

      Returns:
      resources

    • close

      void close()
      Specified by:
      close in interface AutoCloseable
